message.content:
cs.CR, cs.DS, cs.IT, cs.CC, cs.DM 

The paper discusses a relaxation of the notion of memory obliviousness, which is a concept heavily researched in cryptography (cs.CR). The authors explore the efficiency improvements that can be achieved with differential obliviousness in various algorithmic tasks, including sorting, merging of sorted lists, and range query data structures (cs.DS). They also examine property testing and tasks where a non-oblivious algorithm would need to explore different portions of the input, which are topics in information theory (cs.IT) and computational complexity (cs.CC). Finally, the authors suggest further exploration of which class of computational tasks are amenable to differential obliviousness, which is a topic in data mining (cs.DM).
